title: Case Study: Post-Acute COVID-19 Syndrome (PACS) with Persistent Myalgia
clinical_history: A 45-year-old male, previously healthy, presented with a 2-week history of COVID-19 symptoms, including fever, cough, and fatigue. He was diagnosed with mild COVID-19 and managed conservatively. However, 6 weeks post-infection, he continues to experience persistent myalgia, particularly in the lower limbs and back. He reports difficulty performing daily activities due to muscle pain and fatigue.

nprs.affected_area: persistent, aching pain in the lower limbs (thighs, calves) and lower back
intermittent, sharp pain in the upper limbs (shoulders, arms)

aggrevating_factors: prolonged standing, walking, or sitting; climbing stairs; lifting heavy objects
picture: A 24-hour pain profile showing fluctuating pain levels with peaks in the morning and evening
easing_factors: rest, relaxation, and application of heat to the affected areas
medical_history: COVID-19 infection 6 weeks prior; hypertension, controlled with medication
medications: Acetaminophen 1000mg q4-6h prn for pain; Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension
personal_history: married with two children; works as a software engineer; previously active with regular exercise routine, but has been limited due to current symptoms
imaging: None to date; pending further evaluation
